bestBHT.bht: Passing by Mysia, the disciples did not avoid preaching there, but rather omitted it as a preaching place, as they were unable to reach Troas without traversing it. They came down from the highlands and arrived at Troas, a city on the northeast coast of the Ægean Sea, where they could take a ship to Philippi. Troas, also known as Alexandria Troas, was a significant seaport and held the privileges of a Roman colony. This famous city, named after the ancient Troy, had a rich history and was regarded as New Troy by the Romans.

Henry Alford: passing by Mysia, i.e. as regarded their work of preaching
they could not get to the coast without entering Mysia
He may have had the design of crossing to Europe, if permitted, which the subsequent vision confirmed
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: on the northeast coast of the Ægean Sea, the boundary of Asia Minor
on the west; the region of which was the scene of the great Trojan
Albert Barnes: This region was much celebrated in the early periods of Grecian history."
Troas is several times mentioned in the New Testament.
Marvin Vincent: Passing by Mysia. Not avoiding, since they could not reach Troas without traversing it; but omitting it as a preaching - place."
Came down. From the highlands to the coast.
Philip Schaff: Troas. This famous place bearing the name of the ancient Troy was a seaport on the Hellespont, situated some four or five miles from the supposed site of the ancient city.
By the Romans in the days of their greatest power it was regarded as New Troy, and was then one of the most important cities of Proconsular Asia.

In the days of Paul it had not attained to its utmost growth, but it possessed the privileges of a Roman colony, and the law had been assimilated already to that of Italy, these rights having been conferred upon it by Augustus.
Archibald T. Robertson: Passing by Mysia... neglecting it without preaching there."
This city, named Alexandria Troas after Alexander the Great, was the seaport of Mysia.
It was the place to take ship for Philippi.
John Gill: And they passed by Mysia,.... Without stopping or staying there, though they came to it."
Antigonus king of Asia called it Troas at first, because it was in the country, and near where Troy stood, but afterwards he called it, according to his own name, Antigonia.

Lysimachus king of Thrace having got this city into his hands, repaired it, and called it after the name of Alexander, Alexandria; and to distinguish it from Alexandria in Egypt, and other cities of the same name in other places, it was called Alexandria Troas.

bhtAttempts.bht: Passing by Mysia, the disciples did not avoid preaching there, but rather omitted it as a preaching place, as they were unable to reach Troas without traversing it. They came down from the highlands and arrived at Troas, a city on the northeast coast of the Ægean Sea, where they could take a ship to Philippi. Troas, also known as Alexandria Troas, was a significant seaport and held the privileges of a Roman colony. This famous city, named after the ancient Troy, had a rich history and was regarded as New Troy by the Romans.

Passing by Mysia, the disciples neglected it as a preaching place, since they could not reach Troas without entering it. They came down from the highlands and arrived at Troas, a city on the northeast coast of the Ægean Sea, where they could take a ship to Philippi. Troas, also known as Alexandria Troas, was a significant seaport with the privileges of a Roman colony. Its name derived from the ancient Troy, and it held historical importance as New Troy during the height of Roman power.

Passing by Mysia, the disciples omitted it as a preaching place since they could not reach Troas without entering it. They came down from the highlands and arrived at Troas, a city on the Ægean Sea, known as Alexandria Troas. This seaport held the privileges of a Roman colony and was considered New Troy by the Romans. It was from Troas that they planned to take a ship to Philippi, in line with their design of crossing to Europe. Their subsequent vision confirmed this plan.

Passing by Mysia, the disciples neglected it as a preaching place but could not reach Troas without traversing it. Arriving at Troas, a crucial seaport named Alexandria Troas, they planned to take a ship to Philippi. Troas held the privileges of a Roman colony and was renowned as New Troy. Its significance was acknowledged even in the days of Roman power, though it had not yet attained its full growth during Paul's time. The disciples' subsequent vision confirmed their intention to cross to Europe.

Passing by Mysia, the disciples omitted it as a preaching place since their route to Troas required traversing it. Arriving at Troas, a city on the Ægean Sea, they planned to embark on a ship to Philippi. Troas, also called Alexandria Troas, was a significant seaport and held the privileges of a Roman colony. With its historical connection to the ancient Troy, Troas was regarded as New Troy by the Romans, signifying its importance during the height of Roman power.
